creator: jrw@pobox.com
text:
The 'get' task would be more convenient if it supported the resource, classpath,
and classpathref attributes like 'property' does.

creator: carej@us.ibm.com
text:
Given that the purpose of <get> is to retrieve files from URLs, I'm unclear as
to the value of your request.

Can you elaborate further?

creator: jrw@pobox.com
text:
My particular use case is to get an Ant script from a jar file so it can be
imported, but I think it's worth adding for the sake of symmetry with
<property>.  If I can get a file from a resource and parse it, why shouldn't I
be able to get a file from a resource and save it?

If your objection is mainly because you think it's a waste of time, I'd be happy
to implement a patch myself.

> If your objection is mainly because you think it's a waste of time, I'd be happy
> to implement a patch myself.

I'm not a committer, so it's not like my objections really matter...

Anyway, it's not so much that I think it's a waste of time as I think it's an
unnecessary complication of a very simple task and of dubious value to the
larger Ant community.

Granted I'm not familiar with your particular problem, but it seems to me that
it would be far easier to just unzip the file(s) from the proper archive(s) and
use import, as opposed to trying to extract them with <get>.

Is it that you don't know which archive the files(s) are going to be in?
creator: carej@us.ibm.com

text:
And BTW, the new <resource> types of Ant 1.7 already solve that use case it 
seems to me. I don't know them well, but with them, I'd think you can simple 
<copy> the resources you want somewhere, with a flatten mapper or not, etc...

I'm also of the opinion that <get> should be kept small and simple. --DD
creator: ddevienne@gmail.com
mbenson@apache.org
text:
DD beat me to the punch, but, yes, <copy> + resources should be all you need
here, and <get> is HTTP-centric, period.  I am going to close this WONTFIX; if
you need help using Ant 1.7 features for this, please don't hesitate to seek it
on the user@ant.apache.org mailing list.  If we have grossly misunderstood you,
reopen this issue.  Again, my understanding is that you want to copy a java
resource to a local file.

I believe <resource> types are what I needed.  Sorry to waste you guys' time; I
only looked at the Ant 1.7 docs enough to verify that the feature I wanted
wasn't added since 1.6, and didn't see that part about resource collections.
